content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: it's a good puzzle

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Simple and fun. Nice job.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I wrote a solution in Python: print(week[(week.index(today)+n)%7])

Input
* Please delete (e.g., "Mon", "Fri") for simplicity.

Output
* Please delete (e.g., "Sun", "Wed") for simplicity.

Constraints
* Please change << "Mon", "Tue", "Wed", "Thu", "Fri", "Sat", "Sun" >> to {{Mon}}, {{Tue}}, {{Wed}}, {{Thu}}, {{Fri}}, {{Sat}}, {{Sun}}.

Cases
* Each pair of test and validator should be similar. Please revise as follows:

  • Test 1 becomes Mon 5.
  • Validator 1 (Thu 1) remains unchanged, so now Test 1 and Validator 1 are a similar pair.

  • Test 2 becomes Sat 11.
  • Validator 2 (Wed 23) remains unchanged, so now Test 2 and Validator 2 are a similar pair.

  • Test 3 remains unchanged.
  • Validator 3 becomes Wed -1, so now Test 3 and Validator 3 are a similar pair.
  
  • Test 4 remains unchanged.
  • Validator 4 becomes Fri 0, so now Test 4 and Validator 4 are a similar pair.
  
  • Add Test 5: Tue -17.
  • Add Validator 5 where -14 < n < -7, so now Test 5 and Validator 5 are a similar pair.
  
  • Add Test 6 and Validator 6 where n is a positive multiple of 7.
  
  • Add Test 7 and Validator 7 where n is a positive multiple of 7.
  
  • Make sure each day of week appears as input in exactly one test and exactly one validator. The result would be that all 7 days of week are covered in input.

* Please rename the cases appropriately.

Thanks.

Thank you! Now the input is balanced. Let's balance the output too:

There are now 9 tests, and "Wed" is the answer for 5 of them, but none of the answers is "Mon" / "Thu" / "Fri". Could you please adjust [[n]] and the answers to 3 of those 5 cases?

Similarly, for the validators, "Fri" is the answer for 3 of them, but none of the answers is "Sun". Could you please adjust [[n]] and the answer to 1 of those 3 cases?

Take care not to change [[today]] in any cases.

Thanks again.
